raw_text:
Roddick splits from coach Gilbert
 
 Andy Roddick has ended an 18-month association with coach Brad Gilbert which yielded the US Open title and saw the American become world number one.
 
 Roddick released a statement through the SFX Sports Group with the news but did not give a reason for the split. "The decision to not re-hire Brad Gilbert for the 2005 season is based on what I think is best for my game at this time," said Roddick. "Any more on this situation's a private matter between coach and player." Roddick won 121 of his 147 matches while working with Gilbert, and said he had enjoyed their time together. He won his first Grand Slam event at Flushing Meadows last year, and finished 2003 on top of the ATP Tour rankings.
 
 But Roddick slipped to second this year behind Roger Federer, who became the first man since 1988 to win three Majors in a season. Federer, who has not had a coach since he split from Peter Lundgren at the end of last year, beat Roddick to win the Wimbledon title and in two other tournament finals. Roddick hired Gilbert after deciding to part from coach Tarik Benhabiles in the wake of his first-round exit at the 2003 French Open. He went on to win the US Open and four other titles for the year. He has won four events this season. "I have enjoyed all of my time with Andy," Gilbert said on his personal website. "He has been a great student of the game during the time that we worked together and I am very proud of the results that were achieved. "While I believe that there is still a great deal of work to be done, Andy clearly does not feel that way."
llama3.2:1b: Andy Roddick ends 18-month association with coach Brad Gilbert, who led him to two US Open titles and world number one status.
Roddick released a statement without giving a reason for the split, but says it's best for his game at this time.
He won 121 of his matches under Gilbert's guidance.
llama3.2:3b: Andy Roddick splits from coach Brad Gilbert after 18 months, citing it's best for his game at this time, but didn't give reason for split.
Roddick won 121 matches with Gilbert, including the US Open title, and enjoyed their time together.
Federer surpassed Roddick to become world number one, winning three Majors in a season, and Gilbert said he's proud of the results achieved during their time together.

While they achieved success together including winning the US Open and becoming world number one, Roddick now believes a change is needed.
Gilbert states he was proud of the results achieved during their time working together but acknowledges that Roddick disagrees.

He won the US Open in 2003 and has finished in second place this season.
While he enjoys their time together, he believes there is more work to be done for Andy Roddick's career.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Andy Roddick ends his 18-month coaching partnership with Brad Gilbert, who helped him win at Flushing Meadows and become world number one.
Roddick enjoyed working with Gilbert but chose to move on after a successful season, slipping in rankings behind Roger Federer due to the latter's strong performance against him.
Gilbert acknowledged their positive relationship but emphasized that Roddick did not feel as committed this year.
qwen2.5:3b: Roddick ends 18-month association with coach Brad Gilbert following US Open victory and becoming No.1.
Both parties enjoyed working together; however, Roddick decided it was best for his game at the time.
He now trails Roger Federer in rankings after losing Grand Slam titles to Federer who has not had a coach since last year.
Gilbert praised Roddick's development as a student but believes further work is needed.
opencoder:1.5b:
Roddick split from coach Gilbert

Andy Roddick decided against re-hiring coach Brad Gilbert for the 2005 season after considering his personal situation and goals.
He had made an impressive decision during a time of intense competition with Gilbert.
Roddick won 121 of his 147 matches, enjoyed their game together, won Grand Slam events in Flushing Meadows last year, and finished 2003 on the ATP Tour rankings.
However, he also faced Roger Federer who led to a disappointing split from coach Tarik Benhabiles in the wake of his first-round exit at the 2003 French Open.
smollm:1.7b: Roddick ended an 18-month association with coach Brad Gilbert which yielded the US Open title and saw the American become world number one.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Roddick split from coach Gilbert in 2005, leading him to an eight-year reign with him, where he secured the US Open title.
Roddick became world number one following that win.
He ended a six-month contract with Gilbert, who later left for Tarik Benhabiles after his 2003 victory at the French Open.
Roddick won 121 matches out of 147 and is second this year behind Roger Federer, who clinched three majors in a season.
He hired Gilbert to start the 2006 season and secured two more titles for the year.
While Gilbert praised his time under him on his personal website, Roddick expressed doubts about future coach Benhabiles' influence.
tinyllama:1.1b: Andy Roddick ended his 18-month association with Brad Gilbert after having enjoyed a successful run as a tennis player during the time they worked together.

The American finished the season on top of the ATP Tour rankings, winning three Major titles this year, while his fellow countryman Roger Federer claimed all three Grand Slam events he was involved in.
Despite a successful and fruitful partnership with Gilbert, Roddick decided to end their working relationship after noting that they had "enjoyed" their time together.
While Gilbert was initially delighted by the news, he expressed disappointment at Roddick's decision.

The split marks the end of an era for Roddick, who will now turn his attention to rebuilding his career as a coach, hoping to match or surpass the feats achieved by Gilbert and Federer in recent years.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Roddick splits from coach Gilbert, ending an association that yielded the US Open title and made him world number one.
The decision was based on what Roddick perceives as best for his game at this time.
He has enjoyed working with Gilbert and has won four events this season.
While he believes there is still work to be done, Gilbert states he does not feel it's the right time for a new coach yet.

He had won 121 out of 147 matches while working with Gilbert, but slipped to second in the rankings behind Roger Federer.
Roddick had previously worked with coach Tarik Benhabiles before hiring Gilbert after splitting from him at the French Open.

Despite splitting from Gilbert, Roddick fell to second place behind Roger Federer, who won three majors in a season.

Under Gilbert, Roddick won 121 of 147 matches and finished 2003 as the top-ranked player, but he slipped to second behind Roger Federer in 2004.
Federer, who has been without a coach since splitting from Peter Lundgren, defeated Roddick in multiple finals, including Wimbledon.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Andy Roddick has parted ways with his coach, Brad Gilbert, after 18 months, citing it's in the best interest of his game.
Roddick won 121 out of 147 matches under Gilbert, including the US Open title and becoming world number one in 2003.
However, he dropped to second place this year behind Roger Federer, who has not had a coach since his previous mentor, Peter Lundgren.
Gilbert praised Roddick's dedication as a student of the game, while Roddick expressed enjoyment of their time together and emphasized the split is a private matter between them.
